thread.title: Photographer Thomas Heaton capture Britain's beautiful landscapes
thread.title_full: Photographer Thomas Heaton capture Britain's beautiful landscapes | Daily Mail Online

author: John Hutchinson for MailOnline
title: Photographer Thomas Heaton capture Britain's beautiful landscapes
text:
179 shares 17
View
comments
These stunning photographs highlight the beautiful landscapes of Great Britain.
Photographer Thomas Heaton has spent the past two years taking trips to stunning parts of the Lake District, Yorkshire and the Scottish Highlands - and capturing mesmerising images of them.
The 31-year-old photographer, who currently lives in Whitley Bay, explains that landscape photography is his passion.
His striking shots reveal the beauty of the Lake District's Buttermere Valley and the mystical Great Gable Mountains.
Others show the splendour of golden fields in late Spring in Roseberry Topping in Yorkshire.
The landscape photographer said: 'With regards to autumn, I always head to Northumberland or the Lake District.
'Autumn in its full glory is very short lived and can be ruined by a single storm, so the window of opportunity is very short, making it a very special time of year.'
Scroll down for video
Camping allows Thomas to photograph the sunset, night sky and sunrise, all from the comfort of his own tent in the Lake District
A storm at St Mary's Lighthouse in Whitley Bay. Thomas Heaton said: 'Looking out of my window, I saw the wind was changing and it was clear that a storm was brewing'
This image shows the beauty of a temperature inversion as the clouds fill the valley below

Catbells, Derwent Water: A 4am hike rewards the photographer with this stunning sunrise view in the Lake District
Evening light catches the mountain tops over Loch Etive in the Scottish Highlands
Thomas Heaton has spent the last two years taking trips to stunning parts of the Lake District, Yorkshire and the Scottish Highlands. Pictured is sunrise at Buttermere in the Lake District
A beautiful autumnal sunrise at Rydal Water. Heaton said: 'As the dawn light increased I started to get that feeling of excitement'
One way of enjoying nature and being able to witness magical scenes is to camp out on location
A truly glorious sunset over Castle Stalker in the west coast of Scotland and right, gorgeous morning light bathes this isolated island on Rydal Water in the Lake District
When conditions are just right, a temperature inversion can occur. It is a rare and beautiful event and can only be witnessed from high up (Lake District pictured)
The summit of Place Fell, Lake District, bathed in evening light with Ullswater in the far distance
Late Spring at Roseberry Topping, North Yorkshire: After a disappointing bluebell shoot, the photographer was surprised to see that rapeseed had been planted this year
The view from Thomas' tent on the summit of Place Fell in the Lake District as the clouds began to form in the valley below
